Dear Ms. Carey:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 05/19/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all of the following:
(d) Staff qualifications.
The agency requires annual ICHATs and central registry
clearances.
Three of six employee records reviewed where the employee
was employed for over a year did not show compliance:
The respective employee’s annual central registry clearance
was completed over a year with respect to the last one
completed.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Five of six employee records reviewed showed the employee’s
annual performance evaluation due by 9/30/2021 was
completed, 19, 53, 53,53 and 61 days after the period. Each
was more than a year after the last respective evaluation
documented for the employee.
Repeat Violation-Interim 2020.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
4

(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the service plan
must address the living arrangement for the child or children,
visitation/parenting time with the youth's biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or appropriate.
One of three initial service plans or modified service plans
viewed; and five of five updated service plans reviewed were
not in compliance:
One youth’s
 7/20/2021-10/19/2021 USP was completed 16 days late
on 11/4/2021.
 10/20/2021-1/17/2022 USP was completed 3 days late
on 1/20/2022.
 1/18/2022-4/17/2022 USP was completed 8 days on
4/25/2022.
A second youth’s:
 7/31/2021-10/28/2021 USP was completed 5 days late
on 11/2/2021.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2021; Interim 2020.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide
automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”)
which will be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal
reporting requirements.
Three of six closed independent living youth records reviewed
did not show an uploaded copy of the youth’s completed closing
action summary.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
5

FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
Two of four open independent living youth records reviewed did
not show compliance:
 One youth’s record did not show documentation of an
FTM for the youth’s 7/20/2021-10/19/2021 USP. One
was completed after the period on 10/22/2021. This
youth’s record did not show documentation of a FTM for
the youth’s 1/18/2022-4/25/2022 USP. One was
completed sooner than required per policy on 2/28/2022.
 A second youth’s record did not show documentation of a
FTM for the youth’s 7/31/2021-10/28/2021 USP.
Contract-IL+ Independent Living-Plus Contract 2.10.d.4)
Within 30-calendar days of intake provide the youths Life Skill
Coach a copy of the youth’s Independent Living Plus (ILP) plan
and contract, which includes areas of need related to the
independent living skills.
In one of four open independent living youth records reviewed
where the youth was documented as an ILP youth, the record
did not show documentation that the Life Skill Coach received a
copy of the plan, as required by the rule.
Contract-IL+ Independent Living-Plus Contract 2.10.d.6)
A minimum of 4 monthly contacts with the youth.
This shall consist of at least two-face-to-face contacts, of which,
one will be in the youth’s residence. Each face-to-face contact
shall be a minimum of one hour. Remaining contacts may be
conducted in person or via telephone conversation for any
length of time. Phone messages, texts, email or social media
contacts do not replace a required contact but can be utilized.
6

In one of four open independent living youth records reviewed
where the youth was documented as an ILP youth, the record
did not show documentation of the required number of monthly
contacts, as required by the standard.
Contract-IL+ Independent Living-Plus Contract 2.10.d.9)
A minimum of 4 hours per week of IL instruction upon
completion of the CLSA and IL plan and contract. Seventy-five
percent of the IL instruction time per month must be practical
hands-on instruction as opposed to classroom, worksheet, or
online instruction. In addition, 10% of the Il instruction must be
community based.
In two of four independent living youth records reviewed where
the youth was documented as an IL-plus youth, the record did
not show documentation of the number of IL instruction hours as
required by the standard.
Contract IL + Independent Living-Plus Contract 2.10.d.10)
Quarterly meetings with the case manager, youth, life skill
coach and any support persons identified by the youth to review
the CLSA and the pre and post test results.
In one of four open independent living youth records reviewed
where the youth was documented as an ILP youth, the recorded
did not show documentation of quarterly meetings with
individuals as identified and required by the standard.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
Policy FOM 722-8D Treatment plan.
 So as to show that the youth signed the plan within the required 30 days, the
agency was apprised that the treatment shall be consistently dated by the
youth.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Independent Living-Plus Contract 2.10.d.4)
 Having the Life Skill Coach to consistently sign and date the Independent
Living Plus Plan and contract may aid the agency in demonstrating
compliance with this standard.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
7

There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s Renewal Inspection where it
received the following rule violations:
 R400.12509(3)(a) Independent living record- related identifying marks and
photo.
 R400.12509(3)(o) Independent living record- related to service plans.
The agency made progress with its corrective action plan but received a repeat
violation for R400.12509(3)(o) as indicated in this report.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
